Award.AwardTitle: Characterization of a Clathrin-independent Endocytic Pathway in Yeast

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The surface of the cell (the plasma membrane) is the interface across which all communication between a cell and its external environment occurs. A wide range of proteins with different functions is found at the cell surface, and the presence of these proteins at that location tells cells how to respond to signals they encounter. A basic process called endocytosis selects and removes subsets of proteins from the surface, and thus controls how cells are able to respond to a multitude of instructions they receive from other cells. During endocytosis, a portion of the cell surface membrane is pulled into the inside of the cell in a small, spherical structure called an endocytic vesicle. Many different cellular components are needed to both decide which membrane proteins should be internalized, and to actually construct the endocytic vesicle. Work in the PI's lab and others has identified a large number of these components, in particular a component called clathrin and other components that work together with clathrin. These components are found in all eukaryotic cells, so this laboratory has been studying endocytosis using yeast cells, for which powerful molecular genetic tools are available. Interestingly, other eukaryotic cells can also use an alternate, clathrin-independent endocytic pathways, but it has been suggested that the clathrin pathway is the only endocytic pathway in yeast. However, the Wendland laboratory has identified a potential alternate endocytic pathway in yeast that does not depend upon clathrin, and has found some new components that are used instead of clathrin. The project focuses on how these new components enable yeast cells to make an endocytic vesicle.

Broader Impacts: The project proposed here will complement the Investigator's teaching and training mission in several important ways. (1) The undergraduate/graduate students who conduct these studies will learn critical thinking, planning, and presentation skills through writing reports and manuscripts, preparing lab meetings, and attending national annual scientific conferences. The lab has already been actively engaged in the training of underrepresented minorities, and is committed to future training opportunities. (2) The publication of results and the generation of tools and reagents will impact the broader scientific community. (3) The research activities will enhance our current knowledge for three courses; two graduate courses and one large-enrollment undergraduate Cell Biology course. (4) Contributions to the Integrated Imaging Center (IIC) have led to the acquisition of equipment that is used by the broader Baltimore, MD scientific community. (5) A six week module has been developed for a core Genetics Lab course in which undergraduate students conducted a synthetic lethal screen to both aid research under this program and to learn fundamental principles of genetics, while also being exposed to the excitement of performing actual scientific research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outside surface of a cell (the “plasma membrane”) is the interface of a cell with its environment. We study a process called endocytosis, in which portions of the plasma membrane along with some of the fluid bathing the cell, are pulled into the inside of the cell. This removes certain components from the plasma membrane, thus changing the way in which the cell is able to interact with and react to its environment. This is important for cells to adapt to changing conditions, and most cell types use several different methods of endocytosis to respond to these different conditions or to allow uptake of different molecules. During this project, our lab discovered a new way in which cells conduct endocytosis, and this has revealed unexpected roles for well-known cellular machinery. We previously thought that yeast used a single pathway for endocytosis, which relies on a protein called clathrin to stabilize the endocytic sites. Work from this project showed that yeast also use a second pathway that does not need clathrin. Instead, the newly-discovered pathway uses machinery that contributes to cell polarity and generates actin “cables”, which act as tracks that deliver material to sites of cell growth. Many of the proteins that we have identified in the newly-discovered pathway are conserved through evolution. As a result, our studies using baker’s yeast as a model organism raise the possibility that the new endocytic process we discovered is also used by other organisms.

This project also enabled some very significant broader impact activities that incorporated undergraduate students in the process of scientific discovery to support elements of the project. Since 2010, we have worked with students in the Genetics Lab course to conduct a “synthetic lethal” screen, which is helping us to make new discoveries about how both the clathrin-dependent and clathrin-independent endocytosis pathways function. Over 600 students have been exposed to original research practices while also learning-by-doing about fundamental genetic principles such as inheritance of genetic traits, the behavior and function of different types of chromosome elements, and the differences between dominant and recessive mutations. We have also incorporated student-directed research approaches in the Genetics Lab course, where the students were able to conduct experiments of their own choosing to better understand how mutations that affect endocytosis impact a cell’s function. In addition to gaining exposure to research methods, students learned troubleshooting approaches that will assist them in their future endeavors in science, medicine, and other career paths. Some of these students have also joined our lab to delve more deeply into the project. Results obtained so far from the “synthetic lethal” screen have indicated an unexpected role for cellular machinery currently known to act on membranes inside of the cell, instead of on the cell surface at the plasma membrane.
